author: Avani Dias
title: Dylan Voller 'consistently behaving badly in jail', court hears
text:
Map: Darwin 0800 
Prosecutors have opposed a bid by former Don Dale detainee Dylan Voller to be released early from prison, saying he has consistently behaved badly in jail. 
Lawyers for Dylan Voller, whose treatment in youth detention prompted a royal commission, are arguing in the NT Supreme Court he should be released from prison early because he received unfair treatment in jail. 
Voller, 19, was sentenced to three years and nine months in prison for aggravated robbery in 2014, which he is due to complete in October. 
The teenager's lawyers are arguing if the judge who sentenced him knew how he would be treated in prison, he would have been given a different sentence. 
Images of the teenager restrained in a mechanical chair and wearing a spit hood while he was in youth detention in Alice Springs revealed by Four Corners sparked national outrage. Voller 'of consistently poor behaviour' 
Crown prosecutor Trevor Moses submitted progress reports from Voller's time in detention to do with his security classification. 
"They show that Mr Voller has consistently been of poor behaviour while he's been in prison and that is the reason why NT Corrections has been unable to progress him to a low classification," he told the court. 
"[This] has been one of the key reasons by the parole board as to why parole hasn't been granted." 
However, his lawyer David Dalton SC disputed the reports. 
"I object on the basis that these [reports] are allegations [by prison officers] and not deemed to be true," he said. Bid to be released BushMob 
Voller has applied to be bailed to the youth diversion program BushMob. 
Justice Peter Barr said if Voller was granted bail, it would be a test to assess whether the last five months of his sentence would then be suspended. 
"You need to convince me that the sentence imposed ... was not the most appropriate sentence, and another sentence, with the benefit of subsequent hindsight, should have been imposed," Justice Peter Barr instructed Voller's lawyers. 
Voller was eligible for parole in October 2015 but his applications for it were rejected. 
Mr Dalton said Voller had received unfair treatment in detention, as shown in numerous media reports. Psychiatric reports show Voller has PTSD 
Mr Dalton said psychiatric reports showed Voller has post-traumatic syndrome disorder (PTSD). 
However, Justice Barr questioned to what extent his onerous treatment, and as a result his PTSD, had been prompted by his own behaviour. 
"For example, in a completely hypothetical sense, if Mr Voller had been assaulted by an inmate and suffered an injury while in detention then that's been beyond his control," he said. 
"On the other hand, if he had provoked the assault by the fellow inmate in some way I'm not sure it would carry the weight of him being hard done by it." 
The Crown accepted the events in detention contributed to some extent to Voller's PTSD, but said it was up to the judge to decide to what degree that was. 
The matter continues.
